metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The use and limitations of the electrochemical series to explain or predict the products of the electrolysis of particular chemicals, given their state (molten liquid or in aqueous solution) and the electrode materials used, including the writing of balanced equations (with states) for the reactions occurring at the anode and cathode and the overall redox reaction for the cell

electrolytic_cell_definition.name: Electrolytic Cell Definition
electrolytic_cell_definition.correct: An electrolytic cell uses electrical energy from an external power source to drive non-spontaneous redox reactions, converting electrical energy to chemical energy.

spontaneous redox reactions.fix: Galvanic cells use spontaneous reactions. Electrolytic cells FORCE reactions that wouldn't occur naturally.
spontaneous redox reactions.action: Key distinction: galvanic = spontaneous, electrolytic = non-spontaneous (needs external power).

chemical energy to electrical energy.error: That's a galvanic cell, not electrolytic.
chemical energy to electrical energy.fix: Electrolytic: electrical ‚Üí chemical. Galvanic: chemical ‚Üí electrical.
chemical energy to electrical energy.action: Electrolytic cells CONSUME electricity to make products. Batteries PRODUCE electricity.

thermal energy.error: Electrolysis converts electrical energy, not thermal energy.
thermal energy.fix: The power source provides electrical energy to force the redox reaction.
thermal energy.action: Think: you plug it in (electrical input), products form (chemical output).

persistent.gap: You're confusing electrolytic and galvanic cells.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: energy conversion direction, spontaneity, electrode polarity for each type.

cathode_in_electrolysis.name: Cathode in Electrolysis
cathode_in_electrolysis.correct: In electrolytic cells, the cathode is NEGATIVE (connected to negative terminal) and is where REDUCTION occurs. Cations migrate to the cathode.

positive.error: In electrolysis, the cathode is NEGATIVE.
positive.fix: The external power source pushes electrons TO the cathode, making it negative. (Opposite to galvanic cells.)
positive.action: Remember: electrolytic cathode = Sad Red Cat (negative, reduction).

oxidation.error: Reduction ALWAYS occurs at the cathode, in both cell types.
oxidation.fix: RED CAT: REDuction at CAThode. This never changes.
oxidation.action: Cathode = reduction. Anode = oxidation. True for ALL electrochemical cells.

anions.error: Cations (positive ions) migrate to the cathode, not anions.
anions.fix: Opposites attract: cations (+) ‚Üí cathode (‚àí). Anions (‚àí) ‚Üí anode (+).
anions.action: Cations are positive, cathode is negative. Positive attracted to negative.

persistent.gap: You're confusing electrode polarity in electrolytic cells.
persistent.action: Draw an electrolytic cell. Label power source terminals, then trace electron flow to each electrode.

anode_in_electrolysis.name: Anode in Electrolysis
anode_in_electrolysis.correct: In electrolytic cells, the anode is POSITIVE (connected to positive terminal) and is where OXIDATION occurs. Anions migrate to the anode.

negative.error: In electrolysis, the anode is POSITIVE.
negative.fix: The power source pulls electrons FROM the anode, making it positive.
negative.action: AN OX: ANode = OXidation. Electrons leave ‚Üí positive charge.

reduction.error: Oxidation ALWAYS occurs at the anode.
reduction.fix: AN OX: ANode = OXidation. This is true for all electrochemical cells.
reduction.action: Oxidation = electron loss. Electrons leave the anode ‚Üí oxidation.

cations.error: Anions (negative ions) migrate to the anode, not cations.
cations.fix: Anions (‚àí) are attracted to the positive anode (+).
cations.action: Negative ions move to positive electrode. Opposites attract.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on anode function in electrolysis.
persistent.action: Trace the circuit: power source pulls electrons from anode. Species at anode LOSE electrons = oxidation.

strongest_oxidising_agent.name: Identifying Strongest Oxidising Agent
strongest_oxidising_agent.formula: Highest on LEFT side of ECS
strongest_oxidising_agent.correct: The strongest oxidising agent is the species highest on the LEFT side of the electrochemical series. It will be REDUCED at the cathode.

right side.error: Right side shows reducing agents, not oxidising agents.
right side.fix: LEFT = oxidising agents (want electrons). RIGHT = reducing agents (give electrons).
right side.action: Oxidising agents GAIN electrons (are reduced). They appear on the left of half-equations.

lowest on the left.error: The HIGHEST species on the left is the strongest oxidising agent.
lowest on the left.fix: Higher on the ECS = more positive E¬∞= stronger oxidising agent = more easily reduced.
lowest on the left.action: Compare F‚ÇÇ (top left) vs Li‚Å∫ (bottom left). F‚ÇÇ is a much stronger oxidising agent.

oxidised.error: Oxidising agents are REDUCED, not oxidised.
oxidised.fix: Oxidising agents cause oxidation in OTHER species by accepting their electrons.
oxidised.action: The oxidising agent gains electrons = it gets reduced. Confusing but true.

persistent.gap: You're confusing oxidising and reducing agents on the ECS.
persistent.action: Highlight the ECS: left side (oxidising agents) in one colour, right side (reducing agents) in another.

strongest_reducing_agent.name: Identifying Strongest Reducing Agent
strongest_reducing_agent.formula: Lowest on RIGHT side of ECS
strongest_reducing_agent.correct: The strongest reducing agent is the species lowest on the RIGHT side of the electrochemical series. It will be OXIDISED at the anode.

left side.error: Left side shows oxidising agents, not reducing agents.
left side.fix: RIGHT = reducing agents (give electrons). LEFT = oxidising agents (want electrons).
left side.action: Reducing agents LOSE electrons (are oxidised). They appear on the right of half-equations.

highest on the right.error: The LOWEST species on the right is the strongest reducing agent.
highest on the right.fix: Lower on the ECS = more negative E¬∞ = stronger reducing agent = more easily oxidised.
highest on the right.action: Compare Li (bottom right) vs F‚Åª (top right). Li is a much stronger reducing agent.

reduced.error: Reducing agents are OXIDISED, not reduced.
reduced.fix: Reducing agents cause reduction in OTHER species by donating electrons to them.
reduced.action: The reducing agent loses electrons = it gets oxidised.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up where to find reducing agents on the ECS.
persistent.action: Practice: for any half-equation, identify which side has the reducing agent (right) vs oxidising agent (left).

molten_electrolyte.name: Molten Electrolyte Electrolysis
molten_electrolyte.formula: No water present, only ions from salt
molten_electrolyte.correct: Molten electrolytes contain only the ions from the molten salt. Water is NOT present (too hot), so only the metal cation and non-metal anion can react.

water is present.error: Molten salts are heated far above 100¬∞C. No liquid water exists.
water is present.fix: Molten NaCl is around 800¬∞C. Water boils at 100¬∞C. No water can be present.
water is present.action: At molten temperatures, water would have evaporated long ago.

aqueous.error: Molten means liquid salt, not dissolved in water.
aqueous.fix: Molten = salt heated until it melts. Aqueous = salt dissolved in water.
aqueous.action: Molten NaCl(l) vs aqueous NaCl(aq). Different states, different available species.

multiple competing reactions.error: In molten salts, only the cation and anion are present to react.
multiple competing reactions.fix: Without water, there's no competition. The cation reduces, the anion oxidises.
multiple competing reactions.action: Molten NaCl: only Na‚Å∫ and Cl‚Åª. Na‚Å∫ reduces to Na, Cl‚Åª oxidises to Cl‚ÇÇ.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what 'molten' means for electrolysis.
persistent.action: Compare species present: molten NaCl (Na‚Å∫, Cl‚Åª) vs aqueous NaCl (Na‚Å∫, Cl‚Åª, H‚ÇÇO).

aqueous_electrolyte.name: Aqueous Electrolyte Electrolysis
aqueous_electrolyte.correct: In aqueous solutions, water (H‚ÇÇO) is present and must be considered as a potential reactant at BOTH electrodes. Water can be oxidised OR reduced.

water does not react.error: Water is on the ECS and CAN react at either electrode.
water does not react.fix: Water appears twice on the ECS: it can be reduced to H‚ÇÇ or oxidised to O‚ÇÇ.
water does not react.action: Check the ECS. Find both half-equations involving water.

only at the cathode.error: Water can react at BOTH electrodes.
only at the cathode.action: Water can be reduced (cathode) or oxidised (anode). It's a competitor at both.

only at the anode.error: Water can react at BOTH electrodes.
only at the anode.fix: At the cathode, water can be reduced to H‚ÇÇ. At the anode, oxidised to O‚ÇÇ.
only at the anode.action: Include water in your list of species at BOTH electrodes for aqueous solutions.

persistent.gap: You're not accounting for water as a reactant in aqueous electrolysis.
persistent.action: Always list H‚ÇÇO as a potential reactant at both electrodes when analysing aqueous solutions.

water_reduction.name: Reduction of Water
water_reduction.correct: Water can be reduced at the cathode: 2H‚ÇÇO(l) + 2e‚Åª ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ(g) + 2OH‚Åª(aq). This produces hydrogen gas and hydroxide ions.

H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ.error: That's oxidation of water, not reduction.
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ.fix: Reduction of water produces H‚ÇÇ (hydrogen gas). Oxidation produces O‚ÇÇ (oxygen gas).
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ.action: Reduction = gain electrons. H in water gains electrons ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ.

H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚Å∫.fix: H‚Å∫ is produced when water is OXIDISED. Reduction produces OH‚Åª.
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚Å∫.action: Check: reduction adds electrons. The products must account for those electrons.

acid is produced.error: Reduction of water produces a BASE (OH‚Åª), not acid.
acid is produced.fix: 2H‚ÇÇO + 2e‚Åª ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ + 2OH‚Åª. Hydroxide ions make the solution basic.
acid is produced.action: Cathode produces OH‚Åª ‚Üí solution becomes more basic around the cathode.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the products of water reduction vs oxidation.
persistent.action: Memorise: Cathode = H‚ÇÇ + OH‚Åª (basic). Anode = O‚ÇÇ + H‚Å∫ (acidic).

water_oxidation.name: Oxidation of Water
water_oxidation.correct: Water can be oxidised at the anode: 2H‚ÇÇO(l) ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ(g) + 4H‚Å∫(aq) + 4e‚Åª. This produces oxygen gas and hydrogen ions.

H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ.error: That's reduction of water, not oxidation.
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ.fix: Oxidation of water produces O‚ÇÇ (oxygen gas). Reduction produces H‚ÇÇ.
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ.action: Oxidation = lose electrons. O in water loses electrons ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ.

H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí OH‚Åª.fix: OH‚Åª is produced when water is REDUCED. Oxidation produces H‚Å∫.
H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí OH‚Åª.action: Anode = oxidation. Products are O‚ÇÇ and H‚Å∫ (solution becomes acidic).

base is produced.error: Oxidation of water produces ACID (H‚Å∫), not base.
base is produced.fix: 2H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ + 4H‚Å∫ + 4e‚Åª. Hydrogen ions make the solution acidic.
base is produced.action: Anode produces H‚Å∫ ‚Üí solution becomes more acidic around the anode.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up water oxidation and reduction products.
persistent.action: Draw the cell: label cathode (H‚ÇÇ, basic) and anode (O‚ÇÇ, acidic).

inert_electrodes.name: Inert Electrodes
inert_electrodes.formula: Platinum or carbon - do not react
inert_electrodes.correct: Inert electrodes (platinum, graphite/carbon) do not participate in the reaction. Only species in the electrolyte are considered as potential reactants.

react with the electrolyte.error: Inert electrodes do NOT react. That's what 'inert' means.
react with the electrolyte.fix: Inert = unreactive. Platinum and carbon just provide a surface for the reaction.
react with the electrolyte.action: Inert electrodes are spectators. Only electrolyte species react.

copper and zinc.error: Copper and zinc are REACTIVE electrodes, not inert.
copper and zinc.fix: Inert = platinum, graphite/carbon. Reactive = most metals (Cu, Zn, Ag, etc.).
copper and zinc.action: If an electrode can be oxidised, it's reactive, not inert.

must be included in predictions.error: Inert electrodes are EXCLUDED from predictions.
must be included in predictions.fix: Only species that CAN react are considered. Inert electrodes cannot react.
must be included in predictions.action: When told 'platinum electrodes', ignore the electrodes and focus on the electrolyte.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying inert vs reactive electrodes.
persistent.action: Learn the common inert electrodes: Pt, C (graphite). Everything else - check if it could be oxidised.

reactive_electrodes.name: Reactive Electrodes
reactive_electrodes.correct: Reactive electrodes (most metals) must be included in predictions. At the anode, a reactive electrode may be oxidised instead of species in the electrolyte.

do not affect the products.error: Reactive electrodes CAN affect the products.
do not affect the products.fix: A copper anode in CuSO‚ÇÑ solution: Cu electrode oxidises instead of water.
do not affect the products.action: Always list the electrode material as a potential reactant if it's reactive.

only considered at the cathode.error: Reactive electrodes are mainly important at the ANODE.
only considered at the cathode.fix: At the anode, a reactive metal electrode can be oxidised (loses electrons).
only considered at the cathode.action: Anode = oxidation. If the electrode is a stronger reducing agent than other species, it reacts.

always react.error: Reactive electrodes only react if they're the strongest reducing agent present.
always react.fix: Compare the electrode to other species on the ECS. Lowest on right = reacts at anode.
always react.action: A copper anode won't react if there's something more easily oxidised present.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly handling reactive electrodes in predictions.
persistent.action: Practice: copper electrodes in CuSO‚ÇÑ vs platinum electrodes in CuSO‚ÇÑ. What's different?

ecs_limitation_concentration.name: ECS Limitation: Concentration
ecs_limitation_concentration.correct: The electrochemical series is only valid at STANDARD CONDITIONS (1 M concentration, 25¬∞C, 100 kPa). Non-standard concentrations can change which species reacts.

always valid.error: The ECS has limitations. It's not always reliable.
always valid.fix: E¬∞ values are for standard conditions. Different conditions = different results.
always valid.action: Example: concentrated NaCl produces Cl‚ÇÇ at anode, but dilute NaCl produces O‚ÇÇ.

temperature doesn't matter.error: Temperature affects E¬∞ values and reaction rates.
temperature doesn't matter.fix: The ECS is calibrated at 25¬∞C. Different temperatures change the predictions.
temperature doesn't matter.action: Industrial electrolysis often uses non-standard conditions, so experimental verification is needed.

can predict all reactions accurately.error: The ECS only gives predictions, not certainties.
can predict all reactions accurately.fix: When E¬∞ values are close, concentration effects can swap which species reacts.
can predict all reactions accurately.action: NaCl example: E¬∞(Cl‚ÇÇ) = -1.36 V, E¬∞(O‚ÇÇ) = -1.23 V. Close values = concentration matters.

persistent.gap: You're treating the ECS as infallible.
persistent.action: Learn the NaCl example thoroughly: dilute ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ, concentrated ‚Üí Cl‚ÇÇ. Explain why.

writing_half_equations.name: Writing Half-Equations with States
writing_half_equations.correct: Half-equations must include correct states: (s) for solids, (l) for liquids, (aq) for aqueous ions, (g) for gases. Molten species use (l) not (aq).

states are optional.error: States are REQUIRED for correct half-equations.
states are optional.fix: States distinguish between different conditions: NaCl(l) molten vs NaCl(aq) dissolved.
states are optional.action: Always write states. They indicate the physical form of each species.

molten ions are (aq).fix: (aq) means dissolved in water. Molten salts have no water, so ions are (l).
molten ions are (aq).action: Molten NaCl: Na‚Å∫(l) + e‚Åª ‚Üí Na(l). Aqueous NaCl: Na‚Å∫(aq).

all metals are (s).fix: At molten temperatures, metals produced may be liquid. Na melts at 98¬∞C.
all metals are (s).action: Check melting points. Products from molten salt electrolysis may be liquid metals.

persistent.gap: You're not writing states correctly for different electrolyte types.
persistent.action: Practice: write half-equations for molten NaCl vs aqueous NaCl. Compare the states used.

overall_equation.name: Writing Overall Equations
overall_equation.correct: To write the overall equation: (1) balance electrons in both half-equations, (2) add the half-equations together, (3) cancel electrons and any common species.

just add the half-equations.fix: If cathode uses 2e‚Åª and anode releases 4e‚Åª, multiply the cathode equation by 2.
just add the half-equations.action: Electrons must cancel completely in the overall equation.

electrons appear in the overall equation.error: Electrons must CANCEL and not appear in the final equation.
electrons appear in the overall equation.fix: The overall equation shows the net chemical change. Electrons transfer internally.
electrons appear in the overall equation.action: Check your final equation. If you see 'e‚Åª', you haven't cancelled properly.

include spectator ions.error: Spectator ions (like SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª, NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) don't appear in overall equations.
include spectator ions.fix: Only species that change appear in the overall equation. Spectators are unchanged.
include spectator ions.action: Sulfate and nitrate ions typically don't react. Exclude them from equations.

persistent.action: Practice the 3-step method: balance electrons ‚Üí add equations ‚Üí cancel common species.

polyatomic_anions.name: Polyatomic Anions in Electrolysis
polyatomic_anions.correct: Polyatomic anions like sulfate (SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª) and nitrate (NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) typically do NOT participate in electrolysis reactions at this level. They act as spectator ions.

always react at the anode.error: Polyatomic anions are usually spectators in electrolysis.
always react at the anode.fix: SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª and NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª are very stable and don't easily oxidise under normal conditions.
always react at the anode.action: When you see CuSO‚ÇÑ, the SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª doesn't react. Focus on Cu¬≤‚Å∫ and H‚ÇÇO.

affect the products.error: At VCE level, these anions don't affect electrolysis products.
affect the products.fix: Sulfate and nitrate are spectators. They balance charge but don't react.
affect the products.action: Exclude SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª and NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª from your list of species that could react.

must be included in equations.error: Spectator ions don't appear in half-equations or overall equations.
must be included in equations.fix: Only reactive species appear in equations. Spectators are unchanged.
must be included in equations.action: Focus on: metal cations, halide anions (Cl‚Åª, Br‚Åª, I‚Åª), and water.

persistent.gap: You're including spectator ions in your electrolysis analysis.
persistent.action: Make a list: reactive anions (Cl‚Åª, Br‚Åª, I‚Åª, OH‚Åª) vs spectator anions (SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª, NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª).

electrolytic_basics.title: Understanding Electrolytic Cells
electrolytic_basics.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of electrolytic cell fundamentals.

sentences.text: An electrolytic cell converts {{d1}} energy into {{d2}} energy by using an external power source to drive {{d3}} redox reactions.

d1.tooltip: What type of energy does the power source provide?

d2.tooltip: What type of energy is stored in the products?

d3.tooltip: Would these reactions occur naturally without the power source?

sentences.text: In an electrolytic cell, the cathode is connected to the {{d4}} terminal of the power source, giving it a {{d5}} charge, and {{d6}} occurs there.

d4.tooltip: Which terminal pushes electrons toward the cathode?

d5.tooltip: What charge results from excess electrons?

d6.tooltip: RED CAT - what happens at the cathode?

sentences.text: The anode in an electrolytic cell has a {{d7}} charge because the power source pulls electrons {{d8}} it, causing {{d9}} to occur.

d7.tooltip: What charge results when electrons are removed?

d8.tooltip: Which direction do electrons flow from the anode?

d9.tooltip: AN OX - what happens at the anode?

predicting_products.title: Using the Electrochemical Series
predicting_products.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show how the electrochemical series predicts electrolysis products.

sentences.text: At the cathode, the strongest {{d1}} agent present will be reduced. This is the species highest on the {{d2}} side of the electrochemical series.

d1.tooltip: Which type of agent gets reduced?

d2.tooltip: Which side of the half-equation shows oxidising agents?

sentences.text: At the anode, the strongest {{d3}} agent present will be oxidised. This is the species lowest on the {{d4}} side of the electrochemical series.

d3.tooltip: Which type of agent gets oxidised?

d4.tooltip: Which side of the half-equation shows reducing agents?

sentences.text: To predict products at the cathode, look for the strongest oxidising agent - the species most easily {{d5}}. This species will {{d6}} electrons.

d6.tooltip: Reduction involves what change in electrons?

molten_vs_aqueous.title: Molten vs Aqueous Electrolytes
molten_vs_aqueous.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to distinguish between molten and aqueous electrolysis.

sentences.text: In a molten electrolyte, the salt is heated until it {{d1}}. At these high temperatures, water {{d2}} present, so only the {{d3}} from the salt can react.

d1.tooltip: What physical change creates a molten salt?

d3.tooltip: What charge carriers exist in molten salts?

sentences.text: In an aqueous electrolyte, the salt is dissolved in {{d4}}. This means {{d5}} must also be considered as a potential reactant at {{d6}} electrodes.

d5.tooltip: What additional species is present in aqueous solutions?

d6.tooltip: At which electrode(s) can water react?

sentences.text: When water is reduced at the cathode, the products are {{d7}} gas and {{d8}} ions, making the solution more {{d9}}.

d7.tooltip: Which element is reduced from water?

d8.tooltip: What ion is produced alongside H‚ÇÇ?

d9.tooltip: What pH change do OH‚Åª ions cause?

sentences.text: When water is oxidised at the anode, the products are {{d10}} gas and {{d11}} ions, making the solution more {{d12}}.

d10.tooltip: Which element is oxidised from water?

d11.tooltip: What ion is produced alongside O‚ÇÇ? (Think H‚Å∫)

d12.tooltip: What pH change do H‚Å∫ ions cause?

electrode_effects.title: Effect of Electrode Material
electrode_effects.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand how electrode material affects predictions.

sentences.text: Inert electrodes such as {{d1}} and {{d2}} do not participate in the reaction. Only species in the {{d3}} need to be considered.

d1.tooltip: Name a precious metal used as an inert electrode.

d2.tooltip: Name a form of carbon used as an inert electrode.

d3.tooltip: Where are the reactive species located?

sentences.text: Reactive electrodes made of metals like copper or zinc {{d4}} be included in predictions. At the anode, the electrode may be {{d5}} instead of species in the electrolyte.

d4.tooltip: Are reactive electrodes important for predictions?

d5.tooltip: What happens to metals that lose electrons?

sentences.text: When using a copper anode in copper sulfate solution, the copper electrode is {{d6}} than water, so the copper electrode {{d7}} rather than water being oxidised.

d6.tooltip: Compare Cu and H‚ÇÇO as reducing agents on the ECS.

d7.tooltip: What happens when a metal anode is oxidised?

limitations.title: Limitations of the Electrochemical Series
limitations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand when the ECS predictions may fail.

sentences.text: The electrochemical series is only valid at {{d1}} conditions: {{d2}} concentration, 25¬∞C, and 100 kPa pressure.

d1.tooltip: What conditions are the E¬∞ values measured at?

sentences.text: When two species have {{d3}} E¬∞ values, changing the concentration can affect which species reacts. This is why the ECS gives {{d4}}, not certainties.

d3.tooltip: When are concentration effects most significant?

d4.tooltip: The ECS helps us predict, but can we be 100% sure?

sentences.text: For example, electrolysis of {{d5}} sodium chloride solution produces chlorine gas at the anode, but {{d6}} sodium chloride solution produces oxygen gas instead.
Polyatomic anions such as sulfate (SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª) and nitrate (NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) typically act as {{d7}} ions and {{d8}} participate in electrolysis reactions.

d7.tooltip: What do we call ions that don't react?

d8.tooltip: Do SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª and NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª react at VCE level?

electrolytic_basics.title: Applying Electrolytic Cell Concepts
electrolytic_basics.instructions: Apply your understanding of electrolytic cells to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A student sets up an electrolytic cell to electroplate a spoon with silver. The spoon should be connected to the {{d1}} terminal to become the {{d2}}, where silver ions will be {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Which terminal creates the electrode where metal deposits?

d2.tooltip: At which electrode does metal deposition occur?

d3.tooltip: What happens when Ag‚Å∫ gains electrons?

sentences.text: In the electroplating cell, the silver bar used as the other electrode should be the {{d4}} because it will be {{d5}}, releasing {{d6}} ions into solution.

d4.tooltip: At which electrode does the silver bar dissolve?

d5.tooltip: What happens when Ag loses electrons?

d6.tooltip: What ions are released when the silver anode dissolves?

predicting_products.title: Predicting Products Step-by-Step
predicting_products.instructions: Apply the prediction method to identify products.

sentences.text: When electrolysing aqueous CuSO‚ÇÑ with inert electrodes, at the cathode: Cu¬≤‚Å∫ is {{d1}} than H‚ÇÇO on the left side of the ECS, so {{d2}} will be reduced to form {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Compare positions of Cu¬≤‚Å∫ and H‚ÇÇO on the ECS.

d2.tooltip: Which species is the strongest oxidising agent?

d3.tooltip: What is the product when Cu¬≤‚Å∫ is reduced?

sentences.text: At the anode of the same cell: H‚ÇÇO is {{d4}} than SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª (which is a {{d5}}), so water will be {{d6}} to form oxygen gas.

d4.tooltip: Compare H‚ÇÇO and SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª as reducing agents.

sentences.text: During electrolysis of aqueous NaCl, the cathode produces {{d7}} because Na‚Å∫ is {{d8}} than H‚ÇÇO as an oxidising agent - water is reduced instead of sodium ions.

d7.tooltip: Na‚Å∫ is below H‚ÇÇO on the ECS. What gets reduced?

d8.tooltip: Compare Na‚Å∫ and H‚ÇÇO on the left side of ECS.

molten_vs_aqueous.title: Comparing Molten and Aqueous Results
molten_vs_aqueous.instructions: Compare the products from molten vs aqueous electrolysis.

sentences.text: Electrolysis of molten NaCl produces {{d1}} at the cathode and {{d2}} at the anode, because only {{d3}} and {{d4}} ions are present.

d1.tooltip: What forms when Na‚Å∫(l) is reduced?

d2.tooltip: What forms when Cl‚Åª(l) is oxidised?

d3.tooltip: What cation is in molten NaCl?

d4.tooltip: What anion is in molten NaCl?

sentences.text: Electrolysis of dilute aqueous NaCl produces {{d5}} at the cathode and {{d6}} at the anode, because {{d7}} is reduced instead of Na‚Å∫ and {{d8}} is oxidised instead of Cl‚Åª.

d5.tooltip: Na‚Å∫ is below H‚ÇÇO on ECS. What gets reduced?

d6.tooltip: At dilute concentrations, what is oxidised at the anode?

d7.tooltip: What species is reduced at the cathode?

d8.tooltip: What species is oxidised at the anode (dilute)?

sentences.text: For molten MgCl‚ÇÇ, the cathode half-equation is Mg¬≤‚Å∫(l) + 2e‚Åª ‚Üí {{d9}} and the anode half-equation is 2Cl‚Åª(l) ‚Üí {{d10}} + 2e‚Åª. Note the {{d11}} state symbols for molten species.

d9.tooltip: What state is magnesium at molten temperatures?

d11.tooltip: What state symbol is used for molten ions?

electrode_effects.title: Electrode Material Impact
electrode_effects.instructions: Analyse how different electrodes affect electrolysis outcomes.

sentences.text: In electrolysis of CuSO‚ÇÑ with platinum electrodes, the anode product is {{d1}}. With copper electrodes, the anode product is {{d2}} because the copper electrode {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What is oxidised when the electrode can't react?

d2.tooltip: What forms when a copper anode is oxidised?

d3.tooltip: What happens to a reactive metal anode?

sentences.text: The mass of a copper anode {{d4}} during electrolysis of CuSO‚ÇÑ, while the mass of a platinum anode {{d5}}. This is because platinum is {{d6}}.

d4.tooltip: What happens to mass when the electrode dissolves?

d5.tooltip: Do inert electrodes participate in reactions?

d6.tooltip: What property prevents platinum from reacting?

limitations.title: Understanding ECS Limitations
limitations.instructions: Identify when ECS predictions may not hold.

sentences.text: The E¬∞ values for Cl‚Åª oxidation (‚àí1.36 V) and H‚ÇÇO oxidation (‚àí1.23 V) are {{d1}}. This means {{d2}} effects can determine which species is oxidised at the anode.

d1.tooltip: How different are the E¬∞ values for Cl‚Åª and H‚ÇÇO oxidation?

d2.tooltip: What factor can override ECS predictions?

sentences.text: To produce sodium metal, we must use {{d3}} NaCl rather than aqueous because sodium is {{d4}} water on the electrochemical series and water would be reduced instead.

d3.tooltip: How can we eliminate water from competing?

d4.tooltip: Compare Na‚Å∫ and H‚ÇÇO positions on the ECS.

sentences.text: When writing the overall equation, electrons must {{d5}} between half-equations. If the cathode uses 4 electrons and the anode releases 2 electrons, the anode half-equation must be multiplied by {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What must happen to electrons in the overall equation?

electrolytic_basics.title: Mastering Electrolytic Cell Concepts
electrolytic_basics.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by correcting misconceptions and applying knowledge.

sentences.text: A student claims 'the cathode is positive in electrolytic cells because reduction occurs there.' This is {{d1}} - while reduction {{d2}} occur at the cathode, the cathode is {{d3}} in electrolytic cells.

d1.tooltip: Is the statement about polarity correct?

d2.tooltip: Does reduction occur at the cathode?

d3.tooltip: What is the actual polarity of the cathode in electrolysis?

sentences.text: The key difference between galvanic and electrolytic cells is that galvanic cells have {{d4}} reactions and convert {{d5}} energy to {{d6}} energy.

d4.tooltip: Do galvanic cell reactions occur naturally?

d5.tooltip: What type of energy do batteries store?

d6.tooltip: What type of energy do batteries produce?

predicting_products.title: Complex Prediction Scenarios
predicting_products.instructions: Apply prediction skills to more challenging scenarios.

sentences.text: When multiple metal ions are present in an aqueous solution (Cu¬≤‚Å∫, Ni¬≤‚Å∫, Zn¬≤‚Å∫), the {{d1}} metal ion will be reduced first at the cathode because it is the strongest {{d2}} agent.

d1.tooltip: Which of these ions is highest on the left of the ECS?

d2.tooltip: What type of agent gets reduced?

sentences.text: If all Cu¬≤‚Å∫ ions are exhausted during electrolysis, the {{d3}} strongest oxidising agent will then be reduced. This could be {{d4}} if it is higher than water on the ECS.

d3.tooltip: What happens when the strongest agent is used up?

d4.tooltip: Which ion would be reduced next after Cu¬≤‚Å∫?

sentences.text: The overall equation for electrolysis of molten NaCl is: 2NaCl(l) ‚Üí 2Na(l) + Cl‚ÇÇ(g). The coefficient 2 for NaCl comes from {{d5}} the electrons in both half-equations before {{d6}} them.

d5.tooltip: What must be done to electrons before combining equations?

molten_vs_aqueous.title: Critical Analysis of Electrolyte State
molten_vs_aqueous.instructions: Analyse why electrolyte state matters for product formation.

sentences.text: Aluminium cannot be produced by electrolysis of aqueous AlCl‚ÇÉ because Al¬≥‚Å∫ is a {{d1}} oxidising agent than water. The {{d2}} would be reduced instead, producing {{d3}} gas.

d1.tooltip: Compare Al¬≥‚Å∫ and H‚ÇÇO on the ECS.

d2.tooltip: What is reduced at the cathode instead of Al¬≥‚Å∫?

d3.tooltip: What gas is produced when water is reduced?

sentences.text: Industrial production of aluminium uses molten Al‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ dissolved in cryolite (Na‚ÇÉAlF‚ÇÜ). The cryolite {{d4}} the melting point, but the products are still {{d5}} at the cathode and {{d6}} at the anode.

d4.tooltip: Why is cryolite added to the molten mixture?

d5.tooltip: What metal is produced from molten aluminium oxide?

d6.tooltip: What gas is produced when O¬≤‚Åª is oxidised?

sentences.text: The solution around the cathode becomes more {{d7}} during electrolysis of water because {{d8}} ions are produced. The solution around the anode becomes more {{d9}}.

d7.tooltip: What pH change occurs when OH‚Åª is produced?

d8.tooltip: What ion is produced at the cathode with H‚ÇÇ?

d9.tooltip: What pH change occurs when H‚Å∫ is produced?

sentences.text: In copper purification, impure copper is the {{d1}} and pure copper is the {{d2}}. The impure copper {{d3}} while pure copper {{d4}} on the pure copper electrode.

d3.tooltip: What happens to the impure copper anode?

d4.tooltip: What happens to copper ions at the cathode?

sentences.text: Impurities less reactive than copper (like silver and gold) {{d5}} when the anode dissolves and collect as {{d6}} sludge. Impurities more reactive than copper (like zinc) {{d7}} in solution.

d5.tooltip: Are Ag and Au more or less easily oxidised than Cu?

d6.tooltip: Where do the noble metal impurities collect?

d7.tooltip: Are Zn¬≤‚Å∫ ions reduced before or after Cu¬≤‚Å∫?

limitations.title: Critical Evaluation of ECS Limitations
limitations.instructions: Evaluate when and why ECS predictions fail.

sentences.text: A student predicts that electrolysis of 5 M NaCl will produce oxygen at the anode based on the ECS. This prediction is {{d1}} because at {{d2}} concentrations, {{d3}} is actually produced.

d1.tooltip: Does the ECS prediction hold at 5 M?

d2.tooltip: What type of concentration causes Cl‚ÇÇ formation?

d3.tooltip: What is actually produced at the anode from concentrated NaCl?

sentences.text: The ECS predicts products under {{d4}} conditions only. Industrial electrolysis often uses non-standard conditions, so {{d5}} verification is always necessary to confirm the actual products.

d4.tooltip: What conditions are E¬∞ values measured at?

d5.tooltip: How can we confirm what actually forms?

sentences.text: When combining half-equations, ensure electrons {{d6}}. The final overall equation should {{d7}} contain any electrons and should include correct {{d8}} for all species.

d6.tooltip: What happens to electrons in the overall equation?

d7.tooltip: Should electrons appear in the final equation?

d8.tooltip: What must be included for each species?

electrolytic_cell_definition.title: Electrolytic Cells
electrolytic_cell_definition.content: Electrolytic cells use electrical energy from an external power source to drive non-spontaneous redox reactions. They convert electrical energy into chemical energy, which is the opposite of galvanic cells.
keyPoints: Drive non-spontaneous reactions (would not occur naturally)
Used for electroplating, metal extraction, and purification

cathode_in_electrolysis.title: The Cathode in Electrolysis
cathode_in_electrolysis.content: In electrolytic cells, the cathode is connected to the negative terminal of the power source. Electrons are pushed toward the cathode, giving it a negative charge. Reduction (electron gain) occurs at the cathode, and cations migrate there.
keyPoints: Cations are attracted to the negative cathode
Remember: 'Sad Red Cat' - negative cathode, reduction

anode_in_electrolysis.title: The Anode in Electrolysis
anode_in_electrolysis.content: In electrolytic cells, the anode is connected to the positive terminal. Electrons are pulled away from the anode, giving it a positive charge. Oxidation (electron loss) occurs at the anode, and anions migrate there.
keyPoints: Anions are attracted to the positive anode

strongest_oxidising_agent.title: Identifying Strongest Oxidising Agent
strongest_oxidising_agent.content: The strongest oxidising agent is found highest on the LEFT side of the electrochemical series. It will undergo reduction at the cathode because it has the greatest tendency to gain electrons.
keyPoints: Look at LEFT side of ECS for oxidising agents
Will be REDUCED (gains electrons) at cathode
Higher E¬∞ value = stronger oxidising agent

strongest_reducing_agent.title: Identifying Strongest Reducing Agent
strongest_reducing_agent.content: The strongest reducing agent is found lowest on the RIGHT side of the electrochemical series. It will undergo oxidation at the anode because it has the greatest tendency to lose electrons.
keyPoints: Look at RIGHT side of ECS for reducing agents
Will be OXIDISED (loses electrons) at anode
More negative E¬∞ value = stronger reducing agent

molten_electrolyte.title: Molten Electrolyte Electrolysis
molten_electrolyte.content: Molten electrolytes are salts heated until they melt (often 400-1000¬∞C). At these temperatures, water cannot exist, so only the ions from the salt are available to react. This allows extraction of reactive metals like sodium and aluminium.
keyPoints: Only salt ions available to react
Required for reactive metals (Na, Mg, Al)
Use (l) state symbols for molten species

aqueous_electrolyte.title: Aqueous Electrolyte Electrolysis
aqueous_electrolyte.content: In aqueous solutions, water is present alongside the dissolved salt ions. Water must be considered as a potential reactant at BOTH electrodes because it can be reduced (to H‚ÇÇ) or oxidised (to O‚ÇÇ).
keyPoints: Use the ECS to determine which reacts
Products depend on relative ECS positions

water_reduction.title: Reduction of Water
water_reduction.content: Water can be reduced at the cathode: 2H‚ÇÇO(l) + 2e‚Åª ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ(g) + 2OH‚Åª(aq). This produces hydrogen gas and hydroxide ions, making the solution around the cathode more basic.

water_oxidation.title: Oxidation of Water
water_oxidation.content: Water can be oxidised at the anode: 2H‚ÇÇO(l) ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ(g) + 4H‚Å∫(aq) + 4e‚Åª. This produces oxygen gas and hydrogen ions, making the solution around the anode more acidic.

inert_electrodes.title: Inert Electrodes
inert_electrodes.content: Inert electrodes (platinum, graphite/carbon) do not participate in the reaction. They simply provide a surface for electron transfer. Only species in the electrolyte need to be considered when predicting products.
keyPoints: Platinum and graphite are common inert electrodes

reactive_electrodes.title: Reactive Electrodes
reactive_electrodes.content: Reactive metal electrodes (copper, zinc, silver) must be included in predictions. At the anode, if the electrode is a stronger reducing agent than other species, the electrode itself will be oxidised and dissolve.
keyPoints: Compare to other species on ECS

ecs_limitation_concentration.title: ECS Limitation: Non-Standard Conditions
ecs_limitation_concentration.content: The electrochemical series is only valid at standard conditions (1 M, 25¬∞C, 100 kPa). When E¬∞ values are close together, non-standard concentrations can change which species reacts. Example: dilute NaCl ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ, concentrated NaCl ‚Üí Cl‚ÇÇ.
keyPoints: E¬∞ values are for standard conditions only

writing_half_equations.title: Writing Half-Equations
writing_half_equations.content: Half-equations must include correct state symbols: (s) solid, (l) liquid, (aq) aqueous, (g) gas. For molten electrolytes, use (l) for all ions and molten products, not (aq).

overall_equation.title: Writing Overall Equations
overall_equation.content: To write the overall equation: (1) balance electrons in both half-equations by multiplying, (2) add the half-equations together, (3) cancel electrons completely. The final equation shows the net chemical change.

polyatomic_anions.title: Polyatomic Anions
polyatomic_anions.content: Polyatomic anions like sulfate (SO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª) and nitrate (NO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) typically do not participate in electrolysis at VCE level. They act as spectator ions and should be excluded from predictions.
keyPoints: Focus on: metal cations, halides, water
